title: Operation Monitoring Records
description: Requirements for operational monitoring and record-keeping including process monitoring, temperature logs, water quality testing, sanitation verification, and traceability documentation

requirements.text: Are there inspection records for incoming goods (e.g., raw materials, ingredients and packing materials)?
requirements.question: Are there inspection records for incoming goods (e.g., raw materials, ingredients and packing materials)?
mandatoryStatements: Inspection records must be maintained for all incoming goods including raw materials, ingredients, and packing materials
Records must document inspection criteria, acceptance decisions, and any deviations or rejections
Inspections must verify products meet specifications and are free from contamination or damage
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review inspection records to confirm all incoming goods are inspected upon receipt with documentation of inspection criteria, results, and acceptance or rejection decisions. Records should include lot identification, supplier information, inspection date, condition assessment, and any corrective actions when goods do not meet specifications.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should conduct and document inspections of all incoming goods at the time of receipt with records showing consistent application of acceptance criteria. Trends in rejections or quality issues should be analyzed and communicated to suppliers to drive continuous improvement.

requirements.text: Are there inspection logs on incoming trailers (and other forms of transport) for rodents and insects, cleanliness, holes and temperature control of the trailer (for food requiring temperature control for safety and/or as required per buyer specifications)?
requirements.question: Are there inspection logs on incoming trailers (and other forms of transport) for rodents and insects, cleanliness, holes and temperature control of the trailer (for food requiring temperature control for safety and/or as required per buyer specifications)?
mandatoryStatements: Inspection logs must document trailer and transport vehicle conditions before accepting incoming goods
Inspections must check for rodent and insect evidence, cleanliness, structural integrity, and temperature control
Temperature-sensitive goods must only be accepted from trailers meeting temperature control requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review trailer inspection logs to confirm incoming transport vehicles are inspected for pest evidence (droppings, nesting, live pests), cleanliness (debris, odors, previous cargo residues), structural integrity (holes, damaged doors, roof leaks), and temperature control adequacy for refrigerated goods. Logs should show rejection criteria are applied when conditions are unacceptable.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should inspect all incoming trailers with documentation before unloading begins. Trailers failing inspections should be rejected with documentation provided to carriers. Temperature control verification should include checking refrigeration unit operation and product temperature for temperature-sensitive goods.

requirements.text: Are there records for the necessary process monitoring activities (e.g., pH, water temperature vs. product temperature, metal detection, X-ray, labeling, heating processes, reduction/kill step processes, postharvest pesticides (e.g., fungicides), control of water activity, drying, etc.), showing, for example, monitoring frequencies, results and where necessary the corrective actions?
requirements.question: Are there records for the necessary process monitoring activities (e.g., pH, water temperature vs. product temperature, metal detection, X-ray, labeling, heating processes, reduction/kill step processes, postharvest pesticides (e.g., fungicides), control of water activity, drying, etc.), showing, for example, monitoring frequencies, results and where necessary the corrective actions?
mandatoryStatements: Records must be maintained for all critical process monitoring activities relevant to the operation
Monitoring records must show frequencies, results, critical limits, and corrective actions when deviations occur
Documentation must demonstrate processes are operating within specified parameters to ensure food safety
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review process monitoring records to confirm all critical activities are monitored at appropriate frequencies including pH, temperatures, metal detection, heating processes, kill steps, water activity, and other parameters relevant to the operation. Records should show target values, actual results, critical limits, and corrective actions taken when out of specification.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement monitoring procedures for all critical processes with documentation showing consistent monitoring at specified frequencies. Personnel should be trained on monitoring procedures and corrective action protocols, with records demonstrating processes remain in control and corrective actions are effective.

requirements.text: Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial (e.g., free chlorine, peroxyacetic acid) concentration testing of product contact water and ice solutions prior to start up and throughout the production runs?
requirements.question: Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial (e.g., free chlorine, peroxyacetic acid) concentration testing of product contact water and ice solutions prior to start up and throughout the production runs?
mandatoryStatements: Antimicrobial concentration testing records must be maintained for all product contact water and ice solutions
Testing must be performed prior to startup and throughout production runs at specified frequencies
Records must include corrective actions taken when antimicrobial concentrations are out of specification
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review antimicrobial testing records to confirm concentrations of chlorine, peroxyacetic acid, or other antimicrobials are tested before production begins and at regular intervals during production runs. Records should show target concentrations, actual test results, testing frequency, and documented corrective actions when levels are insufficient or excessive.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should test antimicrobial concentrations in product contact water and ice solutions according to written procedures with immediate corrective action when out of specification. Testing equipment should be calibrated, personnel trained on testing methods, and adjustment procedures documented to restore proper antimicrobial levels.

requirements.text: Are there records of monitoring for build-up of organic material (turbidity) and changing of recirculated and batch water systems (e.g., dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, hydro coolers, etc.)?
requirements.question: Are there records of monitoring for build-up of organic material (turbidity) and changing of recirculated and batch water systems (e.g., dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, hydro coolers, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Records must document monitoring for organic material buildup in recirculated and batch water systems
Water change-out records must show when systems are changed according to established frequencies or turbidity limits
Monitoring must cover all product contact water systems including dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, and hydro coolers
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review records showing organic material or turbidity is monitored in recirculated and batch water systems with documentation of when systems are changed out. Records should demonstrate water is changed according to time-based schedules or when turbidity/organic load exceeds acceptable limits, with documentation showing clean water meets quality standards.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should monitor turbidity or organic material buildup throughout production shifts with water change-out occurring before antimicrobial efficacy is compromised. Change-out frequencies should be validated to ensure antimicrobial effectiveness is maintained and water quality remains acceptable throughout production runs.

requirements.text: Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial concentration testing of hand/foot/tool dip stations, and are there stock check and replenishment records for gel and spray stations?
requirements.question: Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial concentration testing of hand/foot/tool dip stations, and are there stock check and replenishment records for gel and spray stations?
mandatoryStatements: Records must show antimicrobial concentrations are tested in hand, foot, and tool dip stations with corrective actions when out of spec
Stock check and replenishment records must be maintained for hand sanitizer gel and spray stations
Sanitation station monitoring must ensure adequate antimicrobial efficacy is maintained throughout operations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review records showing antimicrobial concentrations in hand, foot, and tool dip stations are tested regularly with corrective actions documented when concentrations are inadequate. Stock check records for gel and spray stations should demonstrate adequate supplies are maintained with replenishment occurring before stations become empty or ineffective.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should test dip station antimicrobial concentrations at the start of production and periodically throughout shifts, with immediate replenishment or replacement when out of specification. Gel and spray stations should be checked regularly to ensure adequate supply is available with timely replenishment to prevent periods without functional sanitation stations.

requirements.text: Is there a tool accountability program for knives and similar cutting hand tools used in the production area?
requirements.question: Is there a tool accountability program for knives and similar cutting hand tools used in the production area?
mandatoryStatements: A tool accountability program must be implemented for knives and similar cutting hand tools in production areas
Program must ensure all tools are accounted for through check-in/check-out procedures or regular inventories
Missing tools must trigger search and investigation procedures to prevent foreign material contamination
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review the tool accountability program to confirm procedures exist for tracking knives and cutting tools used in production areas. Program should include tool inventory, assignment methods (shadow boards, check-out logs), regular accountability checks, and procedures for investigating and resolving missing tools before production resumes.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should conduct tool accountability checks at frequencies appropriate to the risk including shift changes, breaks, and end of production. Missing tools should trigger immediate search procedures with production holds if tools cannot be located, and root cause investigation to prevent recurrence.

requirements.text: Is there a pre-operation inspection log?
requirements.question: Is there a pre-operation inspection log?
mandatoryStatements: A pre-operation inspection log must be completed before production begins each day or shift
Inspection must verify equipment is clean, sanitized, and in proper operating condition
Log must document facility conditions including sanitation, pest evidence, and environmental controls
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review pre-operation inspection logs to confirm inspections are completed before production starts verifying equipment cleanliness and sanitation, facility conditions, absence of pest evidence, proper functioning of critical equipment, and adequate environmental controls. Logs should be dated, signed, and show production does not begin until inspection is satisfactory.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should complete pre-operation inspections using structured checklists covering all critical areas before production begins each day or shift. Deficiencies found during inspections must be corrected before production starts with documentation showing corrective actions were completed and verified.

capaInject: Establish corrective action procedures when incoming goods fail inspection criteria including rejection protocols and supplier notification
Implement immediate actions when trailer inspections reveal pest activity, temperature violations, or sanitation deficiencies
Develop procedures for addressing process monitoring deviations including pH, temperature, metal detection, and kill step failures
Create action plans for restoring antimicrobial concentrations when testing reveals out-of-specification results in water systems
Establish preventive measures to address organic material buildup trends in recirculated water requiring more frequent change-out schedules
traceabilityInject: Maintain inspection records for all incoming raw materials, ingredients, and packaging materials with acceptance criteria and lot identification
Keep trailer inspection logs documenting cleanliness, pest evidence, structural integrity, and temperature control verification
Retain process monitoring records showing pH, temperature, antimicrobial levels, metal detection results, and heating process parameters with monitoring frequencies
Document antimicrobial concentration testing results for product contact water and ice solutions throughout production runs with corrective actions
Archive pre-operation inspection logs verifying facility readiness including equipment cleanliness, sanitation verification, and environmental conditions
micro_inject: Incoming raw materials contaminated with Salmonella, E. coli, or Listeria can introduce pathogens throughout the processing environment
Temperature abuse during transportation allows rapid multiplication of pathogenic bacteria including Bacillus cereus and Clostridium perfringens
Inadequate antimicrobial concentrations in wash water fail to achieve required log reductions of E. coli O157:H7 and Salmonella on produce
Organic material accumulation in recirculated water systems depletes antimicrobial efficacy allowing cross-contamination between product batches
Insufficient process controls during kill steps fail to eliminate vegetative cells and spores of Listeria monocytogenes and other pathogens
